core_claim: The longest tennis match in history lasted an astonishing 11 hours and 5 minutes, spanning three days at Wimbledon in 2010 between John Isner and Nicolas Mahut.
source_citation: Wimbledon Championships official records; International Tennis Federation (ITF) archives
why_strange: The fifth set alone lasted 8 hours and 11 minutes, longer than any other complete match in tennis history.

core_claim: During the 1904 Olympic marathon in St. Louis, winner Thomas Hicks was given strychnine (rat poison) and brandy by his trainers to help him finish the race.
source_citation: Official Report of the Olympic Games 1904; Journal of Sports History (1980)
why_strange: The gold medalist was essentially poisoned by his own support team in what would today be considered extreme doping.

core_claim: In 1951, a baseball game between the St. Louis Browns and Detroit Tigers featured a 3-foot-7-inch player named Eddie Gaedel, who was walked on four straight pitches in his only major league at-bat.

supporting_details.outcome: Walked on four pitches, replaced by pinch-runner

source_citation: Official MLB records; Baseball Hall of Fame archives; Society for American Baseball Research
why_strange: MLB had to change its rules after this stunt, requiring all player contracts to be approved by the commissioner.

core_claim: In the sport of Ferret-legging, competitors place live ferrets inside their trousers, which are sealed at the ankles, with no underwear allowed, to see who can endure the longest time.

supporting_details.rules: No underwear, trousers tied at ankles, ferrets must have full teeth

source_citation: The Whole Earth Review (1987); Outside Magazine; Yorkshire Post historical archives
why_strange: Participants voluntarily endure potentially severe bites in sensitive areas from agitated carnivorous animals as a competitive sport.

core_claim: In 1904, Olympic marathon runner Fred Lorz was disqualified after riding in a car for 11 miles of the race before jogging to the finish line and being declared the winner.

supporting_details.outcome: Disqualified; Thomas Hicks declared winner despite receiving strychnine and brandy as stimulants

source_citation: International Olympic Committee; David Wallechinsky, 'The Complete Book of the Olympics', 2000
why_strange: An Olympic athlete tried to cheat by car in a footrace and was almost celebrated as the winner

core_claim: In 1979, a Major League Baseball game between the Chicago White Sox and Detroit Tigers featured a promotion called 'Disco Demolition Night' that caused a riot and forced the game to be forfeited.

supporting_details.organizers: Chicago White Sox, DJ Steve Dahl
supporting_details.incident: Fans stormed the field after disco records were blown up, damaging the field
supporting_details.outcome: Second game forfeited to Detroit Tigers

source_citation: Baseball Hall of Fame; ESPN documentary 'Disco Demolition Night', 2010
why_strange: A music-themed promotion led to a sports riot and an official game forfeiture

core_claim: In 1990, a soccer match in the Congo ended in a 1–1 draw after all 11 goals were scored by the same player—on his own team—deliberately, in protest.

supporting_details.location: Léopoldville (now Kinshasa), Zaire (now Democratic Republic of Congo)
supporting_details.reason: Protest against refereeing decisions in previous match

why_strange: A team intentionally scored 149 own goals in a protest, creating a world record for most own goals in a match

core_claim: Tug-of-war was an official Olympic sport for five Games between 1900 and 1920, with teams often comprising police officers or military personnel.

supporting_details.locations: Paris, St. Louis, London, Stockholm, Antwerp
supporting_details.notable_teams: City of London Police (Great Britain) won gold in 1908; Milwaukee Athletic Club (USA) won gold in 1904.
supporting_details.rules_note: Teams typically consisted of 5 to 8 competitors, pulling a rope over a marked line.

source_citation: International Olympic Committee (IOC) official records, Olympic.org; 'Tug of War at the Olympics' by David Wallechinsky, The Complete Book of the Olympics.
why_strange: A common playground game was once a serious Olympic discipline, contested by professional forces.

core_claim: During the 1904 St. Louis Olympic Marathon, American runner Fred Lorz famously cheated by riding in a car for 11 miles of the race, crossing the finish line first before being exposed.

supporting_details.method_of_cheating: Rode in a car after collapsing from exhaustion, then re-entered the race near the finish line.
supporting_details.outcome: Initially declared the winner, he was disqualified after confessing. He later won the 1905 Boston Marathon.

source_citation: David C. Wallechinsky, 'The Complete Book of the Olympics'; Smithsonian Magazine, 'The 1904 St. Louis Olympics: The Strangest Marathon in History'.
why_strange: An Olympic 'winner' openly cheated by using a car for a significant portion of the race and was nearly awarded a gold medal.

core_claim: The longest professional tennis match in history lasted over 11 hours across three days at Wimbledon in 2010, with John Isner finally defeating Nicolas Mahut in a fifth set that alone lasted 8 hours and 11 minutes.

supporting_details.records_set: Most games in a match (183), most aces in a match by a single player (Isner with 113, Mahut with 103).

source_citation: Official Wimbledon archives; Guinness World Records; BBC Sport archives.
why_strange: A single tennis match lasted longer than many full Grand Slam tournaments combined, pushing human endurance to its absolute limits.
